SUMMARY: YiaJ is a transcriptional repressor that negatively controls expression of genes involved in catabolism of rare pentose l-lyxose [10913096, 9525947, 15870475]. YiaJ is negatively autoregulated, and coordinately represses transcription of divergent yiaK-S operon, related to degradation of l-lyxose [10913096]. Additionally, its operon is activated by insertion of IS1 into yiaJ gene [9525947]. Although little is known about mechanism of regulation of YiaJ regulator, recently it has been demonstrated to act as a repressor by binding to cis-acting elements that overlap yiaKp [10913096]. YiaJ shows high homology to IclR family of regulators; it is composed of two domains, an amino-terminal domain that contains a potential helix-turn-helix DNA-binding motif and a carboxy-terminal region featuring a second motif of unknown function [9525947].
